content:
The Act may be cited as the "Review Every Dollar Act of 2013." It includes a limitation on the reauthorization of federal programs. The "Review Every Dollar Act of 2013" limits the reauthorization of federal programs to a maximum of seven fiscal years. Standing committees must review direct spending programs to determine if they should be modified, terminated, or reauthorized by July 31 of each Congress session. SEC. 102. CRITERIA FOR REVIEW. The House of Representatives and Senate committees must assess reauthorized programs based on effectiveness, cost efficiency, achievement of objectives, alternative methods, duplication, consolidation benefits, and cost per beneficiary growth. The assessment of reauthorized programs includes evaluating cost per beneficiary growth, potential impacts on problems or needs, mandates on State and local governments, hindrance to economic growth, and constitutional authorization. Establishment of Discretionary Deficit Reduction Account under Title II for deficit reduction. Establishment of a 'deficit reduction discretionary account' by the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees. The account is divided into entries for each subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee, with each entry containing a 'deficit reduction balance'. Amounts credited to the account are based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. The deficit reduction discretionary account is established by the chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees, with entries for each subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. Amounts credited to the account are based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. If no statement is made, the reduction in new budget authority resulting from an amendment shall be credited to the deficit reduction balance. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget of the House of Representatives or Senate shall credit amounts of new budget authority and outlays upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill. The chairmen of the House and Senate Budget Committees establish the deficit reduction discretionary account, with entries for each subcommittee of the House Appropriations Committee. Amounts credited to the account are based on reductions in new budget authority or direct spending proposed by Members of Congress. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget of each House maintains a running tally of reductions in budget authority and outlays resulting from agreed-upon amendments to appropriation bills. The Senate and House Budget Committees track amendments reflecting budget authority changes in bills. The calculation of savings in deficit reduction accounts is enforced upon the engrossment of appropriation bills. Upon the engrossment of any appropriation bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the 302(b) allocation for the bill is reduced by the budget authority and outlays calculated. The term 'appropriation bill' includes general or special appropriation bills, as well as supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. SEC. 202. Establishment of direct spending reduction account in Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. Sec. 317 establishes the 'deficit reduction direct spending account' to be maintained by the chairman of the House and Senate Budget Committees. Entries in the account correspond to committees receiving budget allocations, excluding the Committee on Appropriations, with a 'first-year deficit reduction account' and a 'five-year deficit reduction account'. Each entry only includes amounts credited under subsection (c) without negative amounts. Upon the engrossment of any bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the budget authority and outlays shall be counted against the allocation of the applicable committee. Members or Senators offering an amendment to reduce budget authority may state the portion of reduction achieved in the first year. Upon the engrossment of any bill by the House of Representatives or Senate, the chairman of the Committee on the Budget shall credit amounts of new budget authority and outlays equal to the net reductions resulting from agreed-upon amendments. The chairman of the Committee on the Budget credits new budget authority and outlays equal to net reductions from agreed-upon amendments. The chairman maintains a tally of adopted amendments reflecting increases and decreases in budget authority in the bill, available to Members or Senators during bill consideration. The term 'appropriation bill' refers to any general or special appropriation bill, as well as bills for supplemental, deficiency, or continuing appropriations. SEC. 203 of the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 is amended to include new items related to discretionary and direct spending deficit reduction accounts. Additionally, TITLE III discusses budget rules regarding transfers from the General Fund to the Highway Trust Fund that increase public indebtedness. TITLE IV--BUDGETING FOR ADMINISTRATIVE ACTIONS

SEC. 501. REVIEW OF RULES REQUIRING NEW BUDGET AUTHORITY.

This section pertains to the review of rules that necessitate new budget authority. It is in line with budgeting for administrative actions. Chapter 5 of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include a new section, 559a, which requires a review of rules that would need new budget authority of at least $100,000,000 for the fiscal year the rule takes effect or the following 9 fiscal years. The Office of Management and Budget must review proposed rules before they take effect to determine if they meet this requirement. The new section 559a of title 5, United States Code, requires a review of rules that would require new budget authority of at least $100,000,000 for the fiscal year the rule takes effect or the following 9 fiscal years. The Office of Management and Budget must review proposed rules before they take effect to determine if they meet this requirement. The agency may not take further action on such rulemaking. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget may annually review rules to determine if they meet the criteria. The Director determines the transition period for a rule, which ceases to have effect at the end. Exceptions allow a rule to take effect in emergencies, for criminal law enforcement, or national security. Exceptions allow a rule to take effect in emergencies, for criminal law enforcement, or national security. Rules not taking effect cannot be reissued in the same form without specific authorization by law. Judicial review is available for any determination under this section. The Review Every Dollar Act of 2013 defines 'new budget authority' and 'direct spending'. This section applies only to rules with rulemakings starting after the enactment date. Section 1105(a) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to include a statement of the cost of administrative rules projected for the fiscal year. Title 5, United States Code is amended to include a new item after section 559. Title 5, United States Code is amended to include a new item after section 559a, which involves a review of rules requiring new budget authority.
